content: Say that X∙X_\bulletX∙​ is a simplicial set such that some horn filling condition (e.g. inner horns fill, inner horns fill uniquely, all horns fill) holds for horns of dimension ≤n\leq n≤n for some n≥2n\geq2n≥2. Then what is X∙X_\bulletX∙​? Can we say something about sk⁡nX∙\operatorname{sk}_n X_\bulletskn​X∙​ or cosk⁡nX∙\operatorname{cosk}_n X_\bulletcoskn​X∙​?
If n=∞n=\inftyn=∞ then we get a quasi-category/nerve/Kan complex, but I'm interested in the case of finite nnn

I wanted to say something like cosk⁡nX∙\operatorname{cosk}_n X_\bulletcoskn​X∙​ is a quasi-category/nerve/Kan complex, but taking the coskeleton only ensures that boundaries fill uniquely above dimension nnn, not that horns do

One thing I think you can say is that you can ensure that all (inner) hors fill (uniquely) (etc.) by running the small object argument with only horns of dimension >n> n>n, and in particular this will not change the (n-1) skeleton or so
oh that's interesting!

I think I'm looking for something in sort of the other direction though, two sort of related questions:

  1. Is there some name for the structure of having e.g. inner horns filling up to dimension nnn? Naively I'd like to say that e.g. if only 2-horns fill then you have some sort of composition structure, but since 3-horns don't fill, this structure isn't associative.

  2. If I have a simplicial set satisfying some horn filling condition up to dimension nnn, is there some canonical way of extending that condition to all dimensions? My guess would be that it involves the skeleton or coskeleton somehow, as a way to formalise "truncate at dimension nnn and then just add in whatever simplices you need to ensure the filling condition is satisfied".

I think this might be an instantiation of the structure referred to as an An−1A_{n-1}An−1​-category ... in the case of unique fillers it would be instantiated in something like a set or 1-categorial context, and for simple fillers it would be instantiated in a groupoidal or (∞,1)(\infty,1)(∞,1)-categorial context ...
oh, that's interesting! do you have any references to suggest where I can read about this structure?
(note: I also asked this question on MO but didn't get any answers there)

When I hear "AnA_nAn​" I think of Stasheff's pioneering work on AnA_nAn​ spaces, which are spaces with a multiplication that's associative up to homotopy which obeys the pentagon identity up to homotopy which obeys the 3d associahedron identity up to homotopy... and so on, but only up to the nth stage.
The original references to Stasheff are here but I don't think he was working simplicially.
I've heard of AnA_nAn​-spaces but only of AnA_nAn​-categories for n=∞n=\inftyn=∞
(and "A_n-category" is one of those things that is really hard to google!)

Tim Hosgood said:

(and "A_n-category" is one of those things that is really hard to google!)

You can definitely define an AnA_nAn​-category for n≠∞n \neq \inftyn=∞. Though I'm not sure if there's a reason to! Here's the maneuver:

An operad gives you a notion of theory that you can interpret in your favorite symmetric monoidal category, in much the same way that an algebraic theory gives you a notion that you can interpret in your favorite finite product category. Now just like there's an algebraic theory called "groups", there's an operadic theory called "AnA_nAn​" for each nnn (including ∞\infty∞), and we can interpret these in our favorite monoidal category.

For the purposes of this discussion (and the history of the field) it's helpful if your favorite symmetric monoidal category is the category of chain complexes. In this case, an AnA_nAn​-algebra is a monoid (read: a dg-algebra) that's only associative up to homotopy, and these homotopies only cohere up to dimension nnn. So you should think about A∞A_\inftyA∞​ as being the "nicest possible" (things work in every dimension), and as you decrease nnn you're increasing your tolerance for bad behavior (since you're allowing bad behavior to start sooner).

Now we categorify this whole story. We used to have a monoid that was only associative up to homotopy. But a monoid "is" a one-object category! So we can play this whole game again to get a category enriched in chain complexes, where multiplication (read: composition) is only associative up to homotopy! By far the most prevalent notion is an A∞A_\inftyA∞​ category, where we have homotopies in all dimensions, but you can see how to play this game to get an AnA_nAn​-category, which is a category enriched in chain complexes where associativity homotopies only exist up to dimension nnn.
that's a really nice explanation, thanks!

but this seems to indicate to me that the structure I was originally describing maybe isn't an AnA_nAn​-category then? since when you take n=∞n=\inftyn=∞ you should recover quasi-categories/Kan complexes, and A∞A_\inftyA∞​-categories are really models for stable (∞,1)(\infty,1)(∞,1)-categories

(it does so happen that this whole question came to me when working with dg-categories, so maybe there is something AnA_nAn​-happening there, but I'm confused as to how it might apply to the general case)

Traditionally in some fields an "A∞A_\inftyA∞​-category" means one enriched over chain complexes, but it doesn't have to -- it could be defined using an A∞A_\inftyA∞​-operad in any enrichment context, such as spaces or simplicial sets.
The latter aren't then necessarily stable.

something I realised is that, if all 2-horns fill, then you can still define the simplicial/combinatorial π0\pi_0π0​ (and normally you can only define the simplicial/combinatorial homotopy groups for Kan complexes)

Mike Shulman said:

Traditionally in some fields an "A∞A_\inftyA∞​-category" means one enriched over chain complexes, but it doesn't have to -- it could be defined using an A∞A_\inftyA∞​-operad in any enrichment context, such as spaces or simplicial sets.

oh ok, this makes sense then

Yes, an A∞A_\inftyA∞​ operad describes things that are "associative up to coherent homotopy", nothing stable. If you want to study things that are stable, i.e. "associative and commutative up to coherent homotopy", you use an E∞E_\inftyE∞​ operad.

I think Tim meant "stable" in the sense of spectra or chain complexes that already have "additive" commutativity built in, while the extra "multiplicative" A∞A_\inftyA∞​ structure may not be commutative. Like an A∞A_\inftyA∞​ ring spectrum.
Oh, okay. Like a ring spectrum is additively stable but not multiplicatively. But yeah, algebras of A∞A_\inftyA∞​ operads don't need to have any additive structure.
